imho we should probably NOT mount /dev, but rather locations therein... It exposes too many things, and the fact we're hitting an actual SELinux denial on /dev/ptmx is probably not just for the beauty of SELinux...

I'd rather see some more investigations, especially as to "what should we bind-mount". AFAIK, there are a lot of /dev/log usage, explaining most of the /dev mount...

pretty sure we want :rw instead of :ro - else we'll get permission denied again:
14:48:20.543794 write(2, "PermissionError: [Errno 13] Permission denied\n", 46PermissionError: [Errno 13] Permission denied
) = 46

See https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1950176
The problem for iscsid is the contents of interest in /dev are dynamic. The kernel adds and removes entries, and iscsid needs access to the dynamic content.
ack, we cannot "nullify" its /dev/ptmx bindmount, since that would break things in unpredictable ways

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/db/sqlalchem.message: what is the issue encountered with just the original join_depth=1 ?   Is there an expected tradeoff in db access performance with this.

When the PTP parameter belongs to an interface (e.g to set the role as "master" or "slave"), that interface is associated to a host. When the PTP parameter is shown there is a method called 'get_owner' to collect the interface details (name of interface, type, etc.) - see sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/objects/ptp_parameter.py, lines 28-36. Notice that 'host' is a "far" reference (ptp_parameter -> ptp_interface -> interface -> host) and with join_depth=1 I got this message in the output:

"Parent instance <EthernetInterfaces at 0x7fca4043be50> is not bound to a Session; lazy load operation of attribute 'host' cannot proceed"

and PTP parameter information cannot be printed. By cascading the join the result is ok.

specs/xena/off-path-smartnic-port-bindin.message: This seems to be a vender exclusive name. How about we call it NIC-Switch.

Actually, looking at it a bit more, the term "eswitch" is present in devlink itself in the upstream kernel and is used by many device drivers that implement switchdev functionality.

https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/88b06399c9c766c283e070b022b5ceafa4f63f19/include/uapi/linux/devlink.h#L166-L181

It is also used in the "devlink" command-line tool.

Maybe it originated from a particular device driver from Mellanox but it's now a part of the devlink API exposed by the kernel which other device drivers implement.

➜  linux git:(master) ✗ grep -Ri 'NIC switch' | wc -l
4
➜  linux git:(master) ✗ grep -Ri 'eswitch' | wc -l 
1913


I can still use "NIC switch" everywhere if it helps.
OK, works for me. Will change it to "NIC-Switch" instead.

specs/yoga/off-path-smartnic-dpu-port-bi.message: nit: IMO, SmartNIC is enough. Since DPU is mostly well-knowned as NVIDIA's specific production. So it is a smartNIC with extra (data) processing unit. But, for those who has no idea about NVIDIA's production will have no idea about DPU.

There are other vendors calling such devices "DPUs" as well (not in any particular order and not trying to promote):

https://www.fungible.com/product/dpu-platform/
https://www.marvell.com/products/data-processing-units.html

I gave a definition for the DPU term below in the "terminology" section to clear possible confusion as to what I mean by that for the purposes of the spec and feature implementation.

The problem with just calling it a SmartNIC is that this term is quite overloaded already and does not necessarily mean that there is a separate CPU running on a card which is what I am trying to underline. I think this helps with understanding of the scope of the spec.
+1 for terminology, thanks, this spec has many abbreviations due to the topic.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Doing more testing

Questions:
1. Where the hieradata is updated?
2. Looks like the password-rules.conf won't be updated, and once a lock/unlock happens the keystone.conf will be updated with the old rules in password-rules.conf

1 - I'm not sure if hiera is updated. The service parameter values are passed as parameters to puppet in https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/stx-puppet/+/814507

2 - Yes, the way it is now password-rules.conf is not updated, but that should not be a problem I think, as it will take values from service parameters even in case of a host-swact. Let me test if this works with well a host-swact. Thanks for pointing it out.

By the way, I have in another branch here a code snippet to update password-rules.conf as well. I removed it from the spike because It didn't seem to be necessary:


class openstack::keystone::password_rule_update
  inherits ::openstack::keystone::params {

  $unique_last_password_count = $::openstack::keystone::params::unique_last_password_count
  $password_regex = $::openstack::keystone::params::password_regex
  $password_regex_description = $::openstack::keystone::params::password_regex_description

  ini_setting { 'update password rules':
    ensure  => present,
    path    => '/etc/keystone/password-rules.conf',
    section => 'security_compliance',
    setting => 'unique_last_password_count',
    value   => $unique_last_password_count
  }

  ini_setting { 'update password rules 2':
    ensure  => present,
    path    => '/etc/keystone/password-rules.conf',
    section => 'security_compliance',
    setting => 'password_regex',
    value   => $password_regex
  }

  ini_setting { 'update password rules 3':
    ensure  => present,
    path    => '/etc/keystone/password-rules.conf',
    section => 'security_compliance',
    setting => 'password_regex_description',
    value   => $password_regex_description
  }
}

2. What I mean is, in puppet/keystone.py (the keystone puppet plugin) the hieradata for security_compliance is generated from password-rules.conf file. If this file is out of date, the hierdate will be out of date. If puppet is run (lock/unlock) then keystone.conf will be updated with the out of date compliance rules.

1. Replacing release notes content as given below. Is that okay?

---
fixes:

  - |
    IBM GPFS driver `Bug #1947134 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1947134>`_: Fixed
    the initialization of GPFS NFS driver when gpfs_images_share_mode
    is set to copy_on_write by correcting _same_filesystem functionality.
  - |
    IBM GPFS driver `Bug #1947123 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1947123>`_: Fixed
    the volume creation issue in GPFS NFS driver when gpfs_images_share_mode
    is set to copy_on_write.
    the volume deletion issue when volume provider location provides null
    for volume in error state.

2. Wrt volume deletion issue(provider location = NULL), this issue is fixed by line 1600"remotefs_share = self._find_share(volume)" - i.e. volume path is always available with _find_share() method in local_path()
 def local_path(self, volume):
        """Returns the local path for the specified volume."""
        remotefs_share = self._find_share(volume)

The following scenarios are happening with our driver.
1. In copy mode, volume physical file is not created and provider location return as NULL
2. In copy on write mode, volume physical file is created and provider location return as NULL
The following line( remotefs_share = self._find_share(volume)) handles both above given scenario(i.e. It deletes if volume file is physically present during this error scenario. If I use volume provider_location NULL check as a fix then it does not delete the physical file in COW mode)

This fix(remotefs_share = self._find_share(volume)) handles both volume deletion issue(for volume in error state) and volume creation issue in cow mode.

Thanks for the response. Yes, I have experimented/simulated the scenario where volume in error state and volume file did not create in the backend where provider location returns NULL and self._find_share()  returns proper share information. Please let us know if we need to cover any other scenarios in testing.

roles/validations/tasks/list_validation_.message: Can we be more clear here in the comment about the difference between "show history" and "list all history"?  This seems nuanced and a little harder to remember why we need to expand on 'show history', looking at the comment and code.

Here you can grep only:
grep "^[[:alnum:]]\{8\}-"

and use -c UUID

which will result to something less unreadable:

validation history list -f value -c UUID | grep "^[[:alnum:]]\{8\}-" | tee full_validation_history.log

(even -c might be useless, maybe just cleaner since we just want to capture and count the UUID)

or better you can just count with:
$cmd | wc -l
and avoid the big regexp.

The second proposed approach wouldn't work, because other lines might get in the stdout, for example errors. Then we would end up with an incorrect number of lines.

The first alternative is an obvious simplification. But I deliberately went with the exact regex for UUID, to prevent any possible ambivalence about what I'm trying to accomplish.

Hi Elod, 

As the commit message in I92e87282020047c7fad055cae92f2382c4193597 suggests - the team considers the commit to be dead code removal. 

The code that was removed was behind conditions that wouldn't be triggered since deployments wouldn't have nova networks; Nova hard-dropped the nova-networking option in Stein. Manila removed all nova-networking support in Ocata as you note. Hence, this should have no impact on consumers. Removing this dead code was necessary refactoring to enhance some form handling for neutron networking (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/manila-ui/+/796547).

Rationalizing this a bit more:

manila-ui is a horizon plugin - horizon allows speaking to a cloud that's older than it is, sure - but, we don't expect someone running the wallaby to run against a cloud that's as old as Ocata. There are other things that will break if they attempt to. Fundamentally - here's where we request a particular micro-version of the manila API: https://opendev.org/openstack/manila-ui/src/branch/stable/wallaby/manila_ui/api/manila.py#L31 --- a version that's only available since the Rocky release (https://docs.openstack.org/manila/latest/contributor/api_microversion_history.html). So, categorically, manila-ui from this branch *cannot* support anyone that's using it to speak to an Ocata cloud. 

So are we looking at a theoretical impact on backwards incompatibility here?

nova/tests/unit/db/api/test_migrations.p.message:
I looked through the code and I think I see why doing this helps. As you show here, the migration.db_sync() will call migration._get_engine(), which if unpatched, will call the global _TransactionContextManager get_engine() method [1]. The get_engine() method calls the internal _TransactionFactory get_engine() method [2] and that will "start" the factory if it is not already started.

When this test uses the global engine and this test runs before a test using one of the Database fixtures, the Database fixture will blow up when it tries to configure() the global _TransactionContextManager [3] as the eventual call to the internal _TransactionFactory configure() method [4] will raise if it finds the _TransactionFactory already started.

I guess the only reason this fails on a subset of tests is because this test would have to run before any test using Database fixture, which becomes more unlikely the more tests are run in the set.

So, this works to fix the issue.

I note that the Database fixtures use a global SESSION_CONFIGURED to avoid hitting the AlreadyStartedError. I wondered if another way to fix this would be to make the Database fixture call the global _TransactionContextManager is_started() method [6] and do something different if so, but AFAICT it would have to involve swapping a new engine or factory into the global _TransactionContextManager as a reset, because once a _TransactionFactory is started, there isn't a way to reset it to not _started so the fixture could configure() it.

Maybe we want to do that? Not sure. I'm just thinking of how it might be tough to remember to use a local engine for any new non-Database fixture test that might trigger the global _TransactionFactory to "start" if it runs before the first test that uses Database fixture. _TransactionContextManager does have a couple of methods available for doing this: patch_factory() and patch_engine() [7], that are intended for use with test suites. 

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/d7742015f732625ff0c3e455ac5e1c01ba3d9a45/oslo_db/sqlalchemy/enginefacade.py#L819
[2] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/d7742015f732625ff0c3e455ac5e1c01ba3d9a45/oslo_db/sqlalchemy/enginefacade.py#L361
[3] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/e14eef0719eceef35e7e96b3e3d242ec79a80969/nova/tests/fixtures/nova.py#L616
[4] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/d7742015f732625ff0c3e455ac5e1c01ba3d9a45/oslo_db/sqlalchemy/enginefacade.py#L320-L322
[5] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/d7742015f732625ff0c3e455ac5e1c01ba3d9a45/oslo_db/sqlalchemy/enginefacade.py#L790
[6] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/d7742015f732625ff0c3e455ac5e1c01ba3d9a45/oslo_db/sqlalchemy/enginefacade.py#L790
[7] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/d7742015f732625ff0c3e455ac5e1c01ba3d9a45/oslo_db/sqlalchemy/enginefacade.py#L871

cinder/volume/drivers/pure.py.message: Will this allow for keyErrors if either keys "wwn" or "nqn" do not exist
Actually Helen, on thinking about this, there could be a KeyError case, so I have added that in.
Based on the minimum supported API version for this driver, these values will always be available, even if None.

I'm not real clear on what you're fixing here.  Is the issue that if array returns a a port that has both wwn and nqn defined (non-None), we want to ignore it?

Also, your way of addressing the KeyError assumes that if the nqn field is missing from one port, it must be missing from them all.  What is the data contract for the list_ports response from the array?

This is a symptom of older versions of the array firmware. An older array (lower API versions) will never report an NQN field from `list_ports` but a newer version (of the API endpoint) will report that field, even if the value is None. 
Because the response is binary depending on the array version we can use KeyError.
TBH I have another PR planned that will remove this issue for here and other parts of the code.
Probably by Yoga this section of code will change again to be much cleaner, but this needs to be done for our initial NVMe testing

You would want to ignore it as traditional FC ports would need to be zoned seperately from NVMe-FC capable ports, therefore we should not be potentially creating zones through FCZM that cross both FC types.
This code is for the traditional FC (scsi) driver, so we should not be touching the NVMe-FC ports.

Thanks, this explanation is what I was looking for.  You need to say this in your commit message, which currently just says that you add a check, but doesn't say why.

I suggest something like:

  [Pure Storage] Add check for NVMe-FC capable array

  Recent arrays can handle both traditional FC and NVMe-FC ports.  The FC (scsi)
  driver should not be touching NVMe-FC ports because that could create zones
  through FCZM that cross both FC types, so this check makes sure the driver
  only uses wwns that do not have an associated nqn.

might be worth adding a comment after the 'except' saying we're dealing with an older array where NQN is not defined, so we can just ignore it.

I'm still not clear on the check, though.  If the array gives you both wwn and nqn for a port, why do you want to ignore that port?

note for reviewers

the newline after a doc string which is the majority fo this diff is recomeneded by pep257
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0257/#multi-line-docstrings


"""Insert a blank line after all docstrings (one-line or multi-line) that document a class -- generally speaking, the class's methods are separated from each other by a single blank line, and the docstring needs to be offset from the first method by a blank line."""

autopep8 enforces this when https://www.flake8rules.com/rules/E101.html (Indentation contains mixed spaces and tabs) is enabled 

https://github.com/hhatto/autopep8/blob/master/README.rst#features
"""
autopep8 also fixes some issues not found by pycodestyle.

    Correct deprecated or non-idiomatic Python code (via lib2to3). Use this for making Python 2.7 code more compatible with Python 3. (This is triggered if W690 is enabled.)
    Normalize files with mixed line endings.
    Put a blank line between a class docstring and its first method declaration. (Enabled with E301.)
    Remove blank lines between a function declaration and its docstring. (Enabled with E303.)
"""

we coudl disabel E301 and possible E303 if we wanted to avoid that but i think we ant to keep E101 on.

Right, so perhaps given that each task is idempotent (ideally) and non-blocking, an arbitrary pack of those can be safely replayed for affected nodes, from the last known checkpoint in the execution graph, in case of lost/duplicated messages or jobs fingerprints. Unlike to classic handling of lost/duplicating/conflicting operations that require reliable messaging and strong consistency.

So if there is a pull model, and some nodes lost the track, retrying things should not be a problem.

Restarting an orchestration should be a non-impacting event. Because of all the task and job fingerprinting we do, the tools will whole sale omit items from the runtime which match an existing fingerprint and have been accomplished, unless otherwise forced to run again.

Given the deployment jobs idempotent nature (it must be like that) but non-commutative though (the order does matter), if the interrupted graph cannot be properly recovered to continue after the last passed (or to retry from the last failed) job, there is always an option to restart the full deployment from the beginning. I think that should be the main failure mode tbh.

Both token based authentication and CurveZMQ, with Curve25519, has been implemented in Directord; in fact CurveZMQ is the default when running a production based deployment and is tested on every PR.

This is all documented here: https://directord.com/authentication.html

I totally agree, security can not be an after thought. While I still attest we will need a security assessment, the code provides for messaging encryption and tests are active on every PR to ensure we're not introducing known CVEs: https://github.com/cloudnull/directord/actions/workflows/codeql-analysis.yml

That said, there's nothing to elaborate on here. Messaging transport security is an implementation detail in the messaging driver and not something that is provided by Directord itself; while ZMQ is using Curve25519, other messaging drivers will undoubtedly use something else.

Before we moved to ansible, heat provided a similar 'pull' execution model with heat-engine and software config agents on the nodes, with swift as the communication layer. AFAIK, the reasons we moved away from it are mainly due to.

1. Terrible debugging and troubleshooting experience with the 'pull' model.
2. Not supporting a good model for partial and fine-grained (successful) deployment (which we achieved with --limit and other features in ansible)

Can we've some clarity on how those would be addressed with this new architecture? Link to a document outside this spec should be fine.

While Directord is using messaging, it is using a "push" [0] model, similar to Ansible and will continue to do so, the driver is following the router dealer pattern in ZMQ [1] and we intend to do something similar with QDR; nothing in Directord subscribes to the "pull" model. I will spell that out better here.

[0] https://directord.com/overview.html#cluster-messaging
[1] http://wiki.zeromq.org/tutorials:dealer-and-router

Rabi, re: "robust and reliable" and the use of ROUTER sockets. Directord implements an internal heartbeat for sockets and remote clients when running jobs to a given set of targets. These hearbeats monitor the environment and ensure all of the nodes remain active. In the event of a failure, the heatbeat process will cleanup orphaned sockets ensuring that the application remains performant throughout the orchestration or halt an execution in the event required targets are missing. This is a good call out though, the heartbeat process has very little documentation, only being mentioned in the service setup [0] and only referenced once in the data-flow-diagram [1]; I'll look to improve the documentation surrounding the heartbeat process and how Directord recovers from a failure.

[0] https://directord.com/service-setup.html
[1] https://directord.com/assets/Directord-Data-flow.png

The deployment has state. The actual execution status was effectively stateless during processing.  There was no way for heat to know if a node didn't get work because it was client side driven. The proposed architecture with directord include a much more active way of understanding execute status as it relates to the configured nodes.  heat didn't have that when we were using it to orchestrate work on the overcloud nodes during the deployment so thats why we ended up with very long timeouts and no at who lot of status information on the undercloud.

I don't know what we mean by stateless model. Heat definitely had deployment/stack state stored in the heat database, but obviously it was not designed as a task engine to keep state/health of remote workers/nodes.

I would like to know more about 'robust and reliable' part of the new toolset which includes recovery from server/client failure, network issues and queue overflow etc and how those are addressed. 

Though I don't see we using zeromq (rather something like QDR maybe) and don't know a lot about zeromq, here is an example doc snippet from zeromq documentation about heartbeats.

"When we use a ROUTER socket in an application that tracks peers, as peers disconnect and reconnect, the application will leak memory (resources that the application holds for each peer) and get slower and slower."

I'm asking these questions because we're purpose writing some custom tools for our needs and they should just address specific needs and pain points without any overlap.

Heat's problem was using a pull stateless model via HTTP rather than a proper messaging system. The proposed method uses a messaging platform to do work distributed but is additionally more active in understanding state of remote workers.  Heat had no concept of which nodes were still active leading to issues understanding where the entire process currently is. Task-core will push work into directord which is active in ensuring the work is completed before responding to task-core for the next tasks.  The messaging platform replaces the ssh mesh that ansible handles with something more robust and reliable (e.g. developed specifically for this).

specs/xena/directord-orchestration.rst.message: Just a nit, but the above paragraph feels like it should be two paragraphs starting at the sentence starting with "Test clouds" as it is a logical transition point, that or the second two thirds of that sentence maybe split apart.
Ack
developers
Ack
~and~
Ack

Can we spell out the changes to config-download somewhere? Are we going to generate a mix of directord orchestrations and ansible playbooks from the existing service templates during the transition and finally it would only be directord orchestrations?

Also an end-to-end sequence diagram would be useful as the block diagram above does not depict the role of each component in the new architecture and there is lot of ambiguity.

> No thanks. I don't think anyone wants to sign on to write a task graph utility from scratch.

That is not what I proposed. What I proposed was directord + task-core without Heat. A clean room implementation of a deployment using the proposed framework here without having to worry about Heat or backwards compatibility (and puppet for that matter, outside the scope I know). The keystone example is what devstack does. I'd like to see more of that, but what TripleO does.

Taskflow activity and maintenance is a concern for me, but I'm not dismissing on those grounds alone. I don't see any agreement from the tripleo core team about maintaining it, and that *would* be grounds to not use it IMO.

> Your ask here is a bit difficult for me because we didn't ask for any of this before jumping on the ansible bandwagon and have been dealing with the fallout for years now. In this case we've provided scale examples for both task-core and directord at larger scale than we ever tested with ansible or heat.  Why is this such a sticking point *now*?

I don't totally agree with your characterization of the past, but it's valid feedback. If your position is we didn't carefully consider choices in the past, and now we're paying for the fallout, then to learn from that we should carefully consider choices now. Assuming we failed at making decisions on tooling choices on the past, let's not make decisions the same way again. That's why it's a sticking point, and why it's worth all this discussion.

The idea that we can stand up keystone in 5 minutes is not evidence on which to build a foundational choice. We all know it's the long tail of deployment that takes the most time to implement.

My specific ask is that we prove more of that out. Illustrate migrating an actual service template if that's the route we agree on, or do a clean room implementation using directord+task-core with the goal being the end result is the same overcloud architecture.

glance, masakari, octavia also use it.  We're not looking to actually do much in terms of complexity around tasks either.  Right now the issues with the existing unsupported tool is that it's effectively being changed out from under us in an incompatible and less efficient fashion.  It's unlikely that taskflow would have the same issue.

I would agree with James and I think we should carefully examine the option with using Heat as a dependency graph builder (without actual execution). Adding more components (task-core and taskflow) into tripleo violates the simplification trend.

> We are doing things differently this time but it doesn't seem that's being recognized. This spec actually has technical details around scale, etc as those things were completely glossed over in the past but have bit us hard.

I recognize it. Not sure what type of responses you were looking for.

> So I think the issue is how much of a PoC do you want and what needs to be included in it?   We have a PoC to deploy openstack services on a single node. If we need to leverage the existing tripleo services/framework as part of the PoC, there are still issues with trying to integration with THT that perhaps we don't want to do for this PoC. I proposed one path forward in for the adoption patches but they may not be a correct solution since its still trying to continue backwards compatibility.

I'm not going to get into spelling it out as a box to check, because I'm not blocking on the existence of a POC.

What I originally asked for is how someone would  migrate a service template to use task-core/directord, as it wasn't clear to me and not addressed in the spec.  What I wanted to see is a description of how we get from the keystone in t-h-t to the example in task-core. 

A POC would illustrate that, as would an example or pseudo code, it wouldn't actually have to execute. What is tripleo asking of service owners?

As the t-h-t patch shows using ansible-runner, it's also not clear what we would do to not use ansible. I think there were some earlier comments I have not fully caught up on about migrating ansible roles.

The task-core keystone example is more of a devstack type deployment of keystone. The t-h-t patch shows a sample service using ansible-runner. What would the first step be for keystone in t-h-t? Add a core_services output that uses ansible-runner to apply the same ansible roles we do today to deploy keystone?  The end to end dots are still not connected (at least in the spec).

That's what got onto the POC path I believe. I originally asked for pseudo code, or just an explanation of how that would work.

I'm also fine to work that out in the code reviews. It just seemed like there were already some ideas on how this would work and I wanted to see it could be explained or illustrated.

> > The idea that we can stand up keystone in 5 minutes is not evidence on which to build a foundational choice. We all know it's the long tail of deployment that takes the most time to implement.

We did run an execution analysis which is something we should be able to build a foundation upon. The proposal is execution in pseudo realtime, while our current solution has a typical roundtrip of around 1.5 seconds per-task. While keystone in 5 minutes is an example of our current POC the analysis reveals it currently takes half an hour and ~30GiB of RAM to concurrently execute 1000 tasks across 8 hosts, while directord can run the same workload in around 20 seconds with negligible impacts on memory; we've documented this and provided all of the testing materials to recreate the experiment. It is true the long tail of deployment is time consuming, however, foundationally I assert we're starting from a better place.

> Task flow is the initial choice of project to provide a graph processor + execution framework. If we find something else, we can use that.  I feel that the concern about that is nit picking implementation.

Fair enough, if the task-core consumption of taskflow is abstracted in a way that we can swap implementations, I think that would help. Not asking for that initially, but we should think about the possibility.

> As previously mentioned elsewhere, we've done more intrusive changes with less thought than is here. You might not agree but if you look through tripleo-specs vs the major changes we've done you'll see my points about lack of forethought.

I do agree we've made bigger changes in the past with less discussion.

I don't agree with your assessment on how some of the examples you provide have worked out. Regardless though, if it's the case that we failed at those past decisions, then I at least hope we would do things differently this time around, and not hold up those supposed failed decisions as the model for how we should be moving such decisions forward this time around.

> I don't have issues with people raising concerns, however they seems to be things that have been addressed in the provided documentation or not necessarily in scope for this spec which seems like we have a disconnect on explaining the scope.

I will say the spec starts with pretty broad language in the introduction and problem description. I did not nitpick that and tried to focus on the details and proposed change. But perhaps if that were simplified, it would help...

What is the "perfect storm" that we are reacting to?

What is the "course correct"?

"bespoke tools"...yet we are proposing 3 more, and don't illustrate a path for removing any?

Initially the spec didn't say anything about Heat. I do think that has caused some confusion. The example review is for a test service and doesn't show how an existing service template would migrate to use the new interface, nor is it explained how we would get from the ansible-runner driver to something not !ansible. Nor does it address how to remove the other uses of ansible (as dprince has pointed out).

Puppet has also caused confusion. It is included in the same problem description alongside Ansible, so not surprising there is some assumption that it is addressed by the spec as well.

It's not push back, I'm in favor of trying these new tools, but I'm asking if we have ideas on how to approach these other points that the spec itself introduces.

As for the clean room idea, I would say if we just used tripleoclient, roles_data, network_data, task-core, and directord, what would it look like?

If we just illustrated one role, a simplified AIO, then that role would be easy to parse in tripleoclient, and pull the list of services out, then pass that to task-core. The roles_data processing could even be pseudo code, and use a hardcoded list of services.

That doesn't have to be the approach, but what I'd like to see is a minimum AIO (doesn't have to use pacemaker), but should do network config, and the end result should be what tripleo would deploy.

> Please provide the scope of the ask in terms of what type of PoC you are looking for.

Looking at the directord example for keystone, I don't get much sense of how the the existing components (ex. THT, container tools) would tie-up together, maybe it's only me.

It would be better if we've something concrete. Why not have a prototype that deploys undercloud using the proposed toolset. This will give us understanding of the integration issues and complexities.

[1] https://github.com/cloudnull/directord/blob/main/orchestrations/openstack-keystone.yaml

can you check my comment at https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-specs/+/801630/3/specs/xena/directord-orchestration.rst#134

i get that we are adding "core_services" to the role_data output in the service template interface. What is the plan on how we migrate existing services?

How do we move from keystone-container-puppet.yaml to a task-core native definition (e.g., https://github.com/mwhahaha/task-core/blob/main/examples/directord/services/openstack-keystone.yaml).

What is the expectation on service owners? What I'd like to see is an example of migrating an existing service template.

I agree there is overlap between existing and new tools. I'd like to see it more clearly explained how they will work together.

My previous comment on PS3 pointed this out as well:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-specs/+/801630/3/specs/xena/directord-orchestration.rst#36

It feels a bit like task-core is an alternative to heat-as-a-library.

<quote>
task-core is not heat-as-a-library because it takes the cloud services and figures out execution ordering.  Task-core has no knowledge of the data being run and does not put together any of that. It takes nodes/roles/services and figures out what needs to get run in a specific order.
</quote>

Yes, but we could do that with Heat as well. Heat and taskflow are both dependency graphs. Instead of introducing a new tool, we could rework our service templates (required with either tool), and let Heat figure out the specific order. I do have some concerns with using taskflow, as I think we'd need to anticipate maintaining taskflow within our core team.

<quote>
The example of how heat -> task-core works is available via the proposed THT patches https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/798747

Effectively task-core is the ansible playbook parser of the future deployment framework.  There is no plan to use it to replace what heat provides us today. Heat understands the networking/host/roles that we define as our "cloud" where task-core expect you to provide all this information as inputs. Similar to what we have today with ansible where we provide inventory and playbook files.  Task-core becomes the layer between the heat and the actual task executor (directord) similar to what ansible-runner/ansible-playbook provide today.
</quote>

What that patch shows replacing is the parts of tripleoclient that execute ansible-runner (utils.run_ansible_playbook) with inputs to directord, and directord executions.

Can we see an example of what the world looks like the driver is not "ansible_runner" in the task-core tasks?

> For something like keystone, we would remove deploy_step_tasks and populate core_services as necessary.

This is what I'd like to see an example of if that's the plan. Especially if we expect service owners to eventually do this work. If they're going to have to be invested enough to do the work, I think we need to show it at least in a pseudo-code manner.

> Heat does not currently handle being able to feed the execution data into something to run it.

+1

> Heat is good at ordering if it's known upfront, but since we've removed it from the actual framework execution it can no longer handle dynamic ordering.

Yes, but only because of how we've written the service templates. Heat is actually great at ordering. It's a declarative dependency graph, same as taskflow. Even though we've separated the execution from the ordering, we could still use Heat to figure out dependencies and ordering, generate the imperative sequential execution steps, and then pass it off to something like directord to execute. Granted, it would be a significant refactoring in our internal template architecture in how things are laid out. Our usage of ServiceChain/ResourceChain ends up being opaque to Heat, and it has no way to order dependencies between services. That would need to change. I'm not specifically proposing that, Although I would be interested in Rabi's thoughs around this approach.

I'm just a little hesitant to go all-in on taskflow given it is unproven for our needs. With Heat, we have a fair amount of familiarity there, and I don't like the overlap between taskflow and Heat.

> AFAIK Heat allows you to specify specific ordering like we used to use in terms of SoftwareConfig but I don't think it lets you dynamically add ordering requirements at a task level.  

It does, it has depends_on, very similar to taskflow. And it would dynamically figure everything out. Given we've separated that from the execution though, 

The structure of t-h-t has backed us into a corner to where we can't/don't use what Heat can do. And given that we've separated the execution from Heat (necessary, as os-collect-config wasn't cutting it), I'm not sure to what extent we could actually take advantage of it.

> That is not what I proposed. What I proposed was directord + task-core without Heat. A clean room implementation of a deployment using the proposed framework here without having to worry about Heat or backwards compatibility (and puppet for that matter, outside the scope I know). The keystone example is what devstack does. I'd like to see more of that, but what TripleO does.

Please provide the scope of the ask in terms of what type of PoC you are looking for. Is it pacemaker+mysql+keystone+nova+cinder on 3ctrl+1compute? What is the scope we're talking about?  We've put together a PoC that does a standalone of mysql+rabbit+keystone on a single node and showed how it works conceptually already.

> Taskflow activity and maintenance is a concern for me, but I'm not dismissing on those grounds alone. I don't see any agreement from the tripleo core team about maintaining it, and that *would* be grounds to not use it IMO.

Task flow is the initial choice of project to provide a graph processor + execution framework. If we find something else, we can use that.  I feel that the concern about that is nit picking implementation.

> I don't totally agree with your characterization of the past, but it's valid feedback. If your position is we didn't carefully consider choices in the past, and now we're paying for the fallout, then to learn from that we should carefully consider choices now. Assuming we failed at making decisions on tooling choices on the past, let's not make decisions the same way again. That's why it's a sticking point, and why it's worth all this discussion.

As previously mentioned elsewhere, we've done more intrusive changes with less thought than is here. You might not agree but if you look through tripleo-specs vs the major changes we've done you'll see my points about lack of forethought. I don't have issues with people raising concerns, however they seems to be things that have been addressed in the provided documentation or not necessarily in scope for this spec which seems like we have a disconnect on explaining the scope.

> The idea that we can stand up keystone in 5 minutes is not evidence on which to build a foundational choice. We all know it's the long tail of deployment that takes the most time to implement.

True a simple keystone deployment is not representative an actual environment but it's more of a conceptual PoC in that we can do X actions on Y time where as the existing method would take significantly longer. We investigated what we actually do in all the services and as Kevin has pointed out it's somewhere like 50% shell.  And doing shell in ansible is slow so speeding up the execution of the work around processing the actual work on the remote nodes is significant.  We've historically focused on the execution time of the actual work vs the overall time it takes for the deployment process to do that.  We know that whatever keystone-db-manage or script to manage containers is a fixed cost that this effort willy likely not improve. But there's a performance penalty that we've payed repeatedly with Heat/Ansible when we go to actually perform the deployment which is where we're hoping to recover some of the lost performance.  We saw that Heat was faster overall, but had issues with reliability in comparison to ansible.  So we're proposing essentially combining the two methods we've previously used into the next solution via task-core+directord where we get to pick the best of both based on our historical experiances.

> My specific ask is that we prove more of that out. Illustrate migrating an actual service template if that's the route we agree on, or do a clean room implementation using directord+task-core with the goal being the end result is the same overcloud architecture.

Ok, services and architecture do you want for this PoC?
++ Alex to elaborate, but there has been some WIP changes proposed to highlight how everything would work together: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/798747

task-core is not heat-as-a-library because it takes the cloud services and figures out execution ordering.  Task-core has no knowledge of the data being run and does not put together any of that. It takes nodes/roles/services and figures out what needs to get run in a specific order.

Heat (end user UI) -> task-core (figures out ordering/execution status) -> directord (work runner)

The example of how heat -> task-core works is available via the proposed THT patches https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/798747

Effectively task-core is the ansible playbook parser of the future deployment framework.  There is no plan to use it to replace what heat provides us today. Heat understands the networking/host/roles that we define as our "cloud" where task-core expect you to provide all this information as inputs. Similar to what we have today with ansible where we provide inventory and playbook files.  Task-core becomes the layer between the heat and the actual task executor (directord) similar to what ansible-runner/ansible-playbook provide today.

There will be a mix of ansible and directord, at least initially. Through the task-core interface, we'll be able to support both code paths as we transition.

I'll look to building a sequence diagram in the next update.

You are correct that there would be three tools in place of the current two. That said, the two tools we have are the reason why we have horrendous deployment times, where as the three tools we could have would dramatically shrink the install footprint and time to delivery.

>  Right now the issues with the existing unsupported tool is that it's effectively being changed out from under us in an incompatible and less efficient fashion.

There are number of other OpenStack projects and deployment tools that use ansible (openstack-ansible, kolla-ansible etc). As one of the major drivers for this effort is "future direction of ansible" and it's incompatibility, do we've an understanding what are the future roadmaps for those projects look like, or this is driven purely from downstream packaging standpoint?

> i get that we are adding "core_services" to the role_data output in the service template interface. What is the plan on how we migrate existing services?
> 
> How do we move from keystone-container-puppet.yaml to a task-core native definition (e.g., https://github.com/mwhahaha/task-core/blob/main/examples/directord/services/openstack-keystone.yaml).
> 
> What is the expectation on service owners? What I'd like to see is an example of migrating an existing service template.
> 

The existing service definitions can continue it's just different data in the output. We can use a mixture of both to handle migration/upgrades/etc.  The goal is *not* to write new service definitions but rather adjust the role_data output to populate a 'core_services` definition as we work to migrate from ansible -> directord.  This allows the migration to occur under the covers and heat params that used to exist continue to function. Additionally not having even more service files to manage.

Since it's unlikely that it'll get completed in a single cycle, it's something that we want to extend in the framework and come through and remove the legacy tasks as they are replaced.  For something like keystone, we would remove deploy_step_tasks and populate core_services as necessary.  There isn't a specific service we can point to which is why we're point to an example of how the framework would change.  Since the structure of this is still a WIP and up for debate, I would be hesitant to include concrete examples here.



> 
> Yes, but we could do that with Heat as well. Heat and taskflow are both dependency graphs. Instead of introducing a new tool, we could rework our service templates (required with either tool), and let Heat figure out the specific order. I do have some concerns with using taskflow, as I think we'd need to anticipate maintaining taskflow within our core team.
> 


Heat does not currently handle being able to feed the execution data into something to run it.  Heat is good at ordering if it's known upfront, but since we've removed it from the actual framework execution it can no longer handle dynamic ordering. Today ansible is the thing that handles this.  It used to be heat when it was os-collect-config.  Even if we don't have task core, we need an overall task processing/execution thing.  We've seen that heat doesn't work well for that. So if we don't use task-core, what do we use?  Directord is supposed to be a stupid fast execution platform but doesn't handle how to deal with success/failure. Taskflow supports things like being able to define roll back tasks for failures or handling tasks linear-ally or parallel. Heat doesn't do that in this context.  Additionally task-core is acting as a layer for being able to leverage different tooling for the execution as necessary (or for a migration path).  AFAIK Heat allows you to specify specific ordering like we used to use in terms of SoftwareConfig but I don't think it lets you dynamically add ordering requirements at a task level.  The scope of task-core is at a task level such that a task written in nova-db.yaml could just say 'i require database up' and once that happens then it could be run.  That's a runtime dependency that heat cannot handle unless we use heat to perform the deployment orchestration and I do not thing there is desire to go back to that because of other issues mentioned in comments.  In order to do deployment we need an Input Engine (heat & templates), a deployment ordering/management (task-core/ansible) and an executor (ansible/directord/bash/magic).  The overall goal is to break these out into very specific pieces of software and not continue to make something handle things it's not designed for. 


> <quote>
> The example of how heat -> task-core works is available via the proposed THT patches https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/798747
> 
> Effectively task-core is the ansible playbook parser of the future deployment framework.  There is no plan to use it to replace what heat provides us today. Heat understands the networking/host/roles that we define as our "cloud" where task-core expect you to provide all this information as inputs. Similar to what we have today with ansible where we provide inventory and playbook files.  Task-core becomes the layer between the heat and the actual task executor (directord) similar to what ansible-runner/ansible-playbook provide today.
> </quote>
> 
> What that patch shows replacing is the parts of tripleoclient that execute ansible-runner (utils.run_ansible_playbook) with inputs to directord, and directord executions.
> 
> Can we see an example of what the world looks like the driver is not "ansible_runner" in the task-core tasks?


Task core simply calls the executor on the task type.  Depending on the task type used (this would be defined in THT), when the task is "run" by task-core it calls execute: https://github.com/mwhahaha/task-core/blob/main/task_core/tasks.py#L93

If it's an ansible task, it uses ansible runner. If it's a directord task it uses directord.  The results of the execution are processed by task-core when the execution is run (e.g. if failure, stop, if not move on to the next task).

Task-core really gets lists of tasks as input (structured from heat template processing into inventory/roles/services), figures out runtime order dependencies as defined on these tasks and "processes" the tasks. The "processing" of a task is handing the task off to a specific executor (ansible/directord/whatever is written).  The executor does a thing and returns success/fail and task-core figures out what to do next and continues processing until it runs out of tasks.

Today it's heat generating ansible playbooks with ansible-runner doing both the task processing and execution. As mentioned elsewhere there are limits with ansible being able to handle this task processing/execution at scale.  In the future it would be heat generating deployment task data, task-core processing the tasks and calling out to directord (or ansible or whatever) to do the execution.

Also, there seems overlapping functionalities with these tools. We would have three tools (heat-engine/taskflow engine/directord server) providing orchestration/task management functionality, where we had two (heat, ansible) earlier.

> The work in progress review from Alex highlights how we'd integrate [0].

I had seen that example and it does not tell how things would integrated,  once we drop ansible as it's mostly using the config-downloaded playbooks with ansible-runner.

As I mentioned earlier a prototype that deploys undercloud/standalone without ansible would help.

> I don't agree with your assessment on how some of the examples you provide have worked out. Regardless though, if it's the case that we failed at those past decisions, then I at least hope we would do things differently this time around, and not hold up those supposed failed decisions as the model for how we should be moving such decisions forward this time around.

We are doing things differently this time but it doesn't seem that's being recognized. This spec actually has technical details around scale, etc as those things were completely glossed over in the past but have bit us hard.

> "bespoke tools"...yet we are proposing 3 more, and don't illustrate a path for removing any?

So maybe that needs to be clarified a bit more in terms of road-map. I think the first target for removal would be ansible/ansible-runner as a primary path in our deployment process. But it's still TBD on if we can completely remove it for 3rd parties.  I think the description might be adjusted to highlight that the tools choose to perform an action are not necessarily developed with that scope in mind. Lots of scope creep for things like heat/ansible/puppet and what we want is a more unix tool philosophy for smaller tools that do a single thing and do it well rather than larger tools that do many things marginally adequately. 

> As for the clean room idea, I would say if we just used tripleoclient, roles_data, network_data, task-core, and directord, what would it look like?

I talked to Kevin an we're going to try and construct something that deploys openstack from after baremetal & network provisioning for comparison sake. Using a basic 3ctl+1compute (no pacemaker).  network data application is just execution of os-net-config after putting a file in place. I don't think this is really valuable in a PoC context.

> If we just illustrated one role, a simplified AIO, then that role would be easy to parse in tripleoclient, and pull the list of services out, then pass that to task-core. The roles_data processing could even be pseudo code, and use a hardcoded list of services.

You need to scope what you consider AIO. We use just a keystone AIO for updates CI. So we've already done your PoC ask by one definition of AIO. 

> That doesn't have to be the approach, but what I'd like to see is a minimum AIO (doesn't have to use pacemaker), but should do network config, and the end result should be what tripleo would deploy.

So I think the issue is how much of a PoC do you want and what needs to be included in it?   We have a PoC to deploy openstack services on a single node. If we need to leverage the existing tripleo services/framework as part of the PoC, there are still issues with trying to integration with THT that perhaps we don't want to do for this PoC. I proposed one path forward in for the adoption patches but they may not be a correct solution since its still trying to continue backwards compatibility.

> Looking at the directord example for keystone, I don't get much sense of how the the existing components (ex. THT, container tools) would tie-up together, maybe it's only me.

The example in directord was something we put together to show we could deploy keystone, and it's supporting services, in a multi-node setup; that example does not highlight any TripleO integrations. The work in progress review from Alex highlights how we'd integrate [0].

> There are number of other OpenStack projects and deployment tools that use ansible (openstack-ansible, kolla-ansible etc). As one of the major drivers for this effort is "future direction of ansible" and it's incompatibility, do we've an understanding what are the future roadmaps for those projects look like, or this is driven purely from downstream packaging standpoint?

Downstream packaging is a significant huddle for us. In terms of other OpenStack deployment tooling, projects like OpenStack-Ansible builds everything from source so the issue of packaging will almost never be problem; if memory serves, this is mostly true for Kolla-Ansible as well. While we may be able to keep everything operational upstream, that isn't true downstream and operational doesn't mean we'd be inline with the community.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/798747

> This is what I'd like to see an example of if that's the plan. Especially if we expect service owners to eventually do this work. If they're going to have to be invested enough to do the work, I think we need to show it at least in a pseudo-code manner.

Honestly we've done more with less in spec form.  I appreciate this however I think the examples provided are sufficient because they are the tasks that would effectively be included into the existing THT services.  

> Yes, but only because of how we've written the service templates. Heat is actually great at ordering. It's a declarative dependency graph, same as taskflow. Even though we've separated the execution from the ordering, we could still use Heat to figure out dependencies and ordering, generate the imperative sequential execution steps, and then pass it off to something like directord to execute. Granted, it would be a significant refactoring in our internal template architecture in how things are laid out. Our usage of ServiceChain/ResourceChain ends up being opaque to Heat, and it has no way to order dependencies between services. That would need to change. I'm not specifically proposing that, Although I would be interested in Rabi's thoughs around this approach.


The goal here is to maintain backwards compatibility so that maybe we could actually backport and leverage this for upgrades.  We could leverage both but the issue really comes around run time dynamic execution order which heat won't solve. We could leverage the service chain for some elements of execution to restrict the scope of the execution ordering but today we already have this concept in ansible.  We're honestly not proposing anything new here but rather simplifying and explicitly using smaller code bases to handle the function. Right now this functionality is spread across heat/ansible.  The goal would be to have heat process templates and handle dynamic configuration information. Task-core figures out ordering based on what is inputted. Directord does the execution.  


> I would agree with James and I think we should carefully examine the option with using Heat as a dependency graph builder (without actual execution). Adding more components (task-core and taskflow) into tripleo violates the simplification trend.

As just mentioned this is already a thing today in ansible. It's simplification because the code to handle the functionality is scoped to a specific project and doesn't include tons of code that we don't actually leverage (e.g. ansible).

That's not quite what I said.

My concern is more about taskflow, as I'd want to see agreement that the core team is willing to maintain that going forward. Just like we do with Heat and Ansible. I don't think we know enough now to make that agreement. We'd have to prove it out with a POC that is at least on scale with the complexity of an existing tripleo deployment.

I don't see a lot of activity in taskflow, and even if there were, activity isn't a predictable indicator of future maintenance (see Heat, Mistral, Ansible).

I'm more leaning towards one or the other (Heat or taskflow or something else). That is why I proposed the alternative in my comment about clean room, with support for opt-in backwards compatibility.

> I don't see a lot of activity in taskflow, and even if there were, activity isn't a predictable indicator of future maintenance (see Heat, Mistral, Ansible).
> 
> I'm more leaning towards one or the other (Heat or taskflow or something else). That is why I proposed the alternative in my comment about clean room, with support for opt-in backwards compatibility.

No thanks. I don't think anyone wants to sign on to write a task graph utility from scratch. We already have 3 as you've mentioned. Heat, Ansible, Taskflow.  All three overlap here but only *1* is specifically for this functionality. Taskflow.  Yes it's low in activity but it's core to things like VM creation in nova or volume creation in Cinder.  I keep pointing out that the goal is to simplify by using tools *specifically* designed for a function to reduce the issues we have.  In terms of execution testing, we've already tested task-core at a scale larger than tripleo and have tools to show that it can handle the number of tasks with various relationships.

https://github.com/mwhahaha/task-core/blob/main/examples/scale/gen_scale_data.py

Your ask here is a bit difficult for me because we didn't ask for any of this before jumping on the ansible bandwagon and have been dealing with the fallout for years now. In this case we've provided scale examples for both task-core and directord at larger scale than we ever tested with ansible or heat.  Why is this such a sticking point *now*?
+1 we'll work on a more complete prototype and get back to this spec with the results / examples.

> Yes it's low in activity but it's core to things like VM creation in nova or volume creation in Cinder. 

AAFAIK, usage of taskflow in openstack projects have very limited scope and is not tested at the scale/scope we want to use it for. For example, cinder volume creation uses a linear flow[1].  There were some discussions long time back for heat to use it, but never looked at it properly. I'm not saying it won't be good enough for our use-cases, but as I raised earlier it's like kinda moving to one unsupported tool (read ansible) to another.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/scheduler/flows/create_volume.py#L167

The problem description implies that puppet will be replaced for config generation. Can this be captured in the work items? I'm assuming the migration path would start with replacing puppet invocations with equivalent ansible?

Also it might be worth identifying what work items other teams can do to migrate their own services to the new model - this is what we did for the move to containers. This would ease the development workload on the tripleo team and help with knowledge transfer and general buy-in

Port ansible roles does not imply anything about puppet (ansible roles don't handly any of this). Puppet executions are separate action embedded in the framework today.  There is no current desire to replace that along with the actual task execution methods at this time.  In the future if we decide to break the existing hieradata interface that customers and 3rd parties have relied on for years, that will be a separate effort.

Puppet is part of the problem statement because it is one of the many layers of abstractions we have. With task-core we'll support a mixed ansible/directord environment but should we move forward with the spec, development of new ansible based functionality would stop. While puppet will remain at play, due to how deeply embedded it is in some places, we'll look for opportunities to replace redundant capabilities; just as we did when we began the tripleo-ansible push.

specs/xena/directord-orchestration.rst.message: If not, it might be time for TripleO to consider renaming it's project or embracing a new identity because the identity which it started with, as suggested by this specification, is going to systematically removed. The core team identity would no longer be openstack on openstack.  Plus side: t-shirts that don't confuse people outside of our community's circle. Actually, maybe the project should rename regardless. :)
edit: *if folks want to invest in a rename*

I agree, the original idea of OpenStack on OpenStack is no longer at play; even today, without this spec. 

I would love less confusing conference swag 😊

This specific spec doesn't propose removing any more OpenStack API's (Heat, Ironic, Neutron, Keystone still used).

Renames have come up in the past, and personally I don't support it as it feels like wasted energy to me. It's just a name, it does not have to imply anything or mean anything. I'm rather indifferent in folks what to invest in a rename, I just don't think it's worth it.

Originally, it had a distinct meaning (OpenStack on OpenStack), but even that has little significance with changes that are multiple years old by now (e.g. Big Tent). Kolla, Kayobe, openstack-ansible are also "OpenStack". Are they not also OpenStack on OpenStack? I'd argue the original meaning was never well understood anyway, and I don't see a lot of confusion existing today either.

Mission statements, goals, and strategies certainly should be changed and evolved as needed to reflect reality.

this just means directord is aware of the nodes it's managing, outside of just task execution. (e.g., --list-nodes). It's a fundamental characteristic of the messaging architecture. Opposed to something like Ansible, which has no knowledge of nodes it can manage until it actually goes to try and manage them (execute a task).

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Says who? This certainly won't be true when newer versions of Python such as 3.9 are added as those are currently failing on Fedora hosts

Unit tests and functional tests can be run this way. Anything else that depends on the default basepython cannot. tox doesn't provide a way to say e.g.

  basepython = >=python3.6,<python3.9

So this seems a reasonable way to do this.

What is this breaking for you? The current configuration is broken for users with Fedora 34, which fwict is a significant proportion of active nova developers. I suspect this will break the ability of Ubuntu 20.04 users to run lower-constraints jobs and of CentOS 8 users to run the jobs using the default Python version. The former doesn't seem like a massive deal, though I imagine the latter could be annoying. If the latter is the big issue, how about doing a partial revert of the top-level basepython change and keeping the one in lower-constraints (which is the real issue I wanted to solve - the other part was just so Fedora users could run 'tox -e functional' again)?

Ultimately I want a situation when 'tox -e lower-constraints' doesn't attempt to use Python 3.9 and fail. Whatever gets us there will wfm.

So unit and functional tests targets works with any python version in the supported range if specified explicitly e.g: tox -e py37 So there I don't think here the original change introduced a big break. I.e. explicit is always better than implicit. (I personally used explicit versions for unit and functional tests always and therefore I did not have any issue with the original change.)

After the original patch the lower-constraints target only runs if you have py36 installed. I consider this as breaking change as I could run that before (implicitly using the highest python version installed) without py36. Can we simply resolve this by adding explicit targets like lower-constraint-py38 ?

Interestingly if I revert the lower-constraints part of the original change then for some unknown reason in my debian env where py39 is the default python interpreter tox does not try to use that for the lower-constraints target, but selects py38 instead.
hm there are other targets that cannot be explicitly called with python version. like at least fast8, pep8, mypy. So the original change breaks thing there too.

Um, they do?

  tox -e py36

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I am ok with this, if we get failure in higher python like 3.10 or so then it is good early signal to know and fix.
Okay lets do this but I might end up crying again when 3.10 becomes the default on Fedora and tox -e functional starts failing.

Having an account here is an optional thing, right?

So once this is up, everyone will be subscribed to their old lists; but if they want to make use of the hyperkitty interface they need to do a separate sign-up step in that application?  and then they can manage their subscriptions  (which we have migrated for them) interactively from hyperkitty because it's all keyed together by email-address?

It relies on Django, so can use Django plugins for other authentication mechanisms and external account identifiers. I would consider that out of scope for the initial implementation since we don't have it in MM2 and lack any means of easily mapping existing users to external IDs (but they could in theory do it themselves once we add such a feature). I'll add a note about it.

Yes, accounts are for managing preferences and also for using the Web UI to post to the lists instead of E-mail if that's your bag (and for things like list moderation and the admin configuration interface). Technically all subscribers have "accounts" I think (just like in the version we're using) but you don't need to authenticate to send to the lists via SMTP.

It'll definitely need some migration testing, but I expect existing subscribers will use the password reset feature if they need to get access to their account, while new subscribers will create an account when subscribing. However unlike in our version, your account spans all the lists on the server (across multiple domains even).

Maybe not relevant for the initial migration, but is there an option to rely on some external authentication that might unify our different account setups or is this necessarily a world of its own just for mailman?

Did you consider running the within containers, too? Would be nice to at least have a short sentence about why to prefer using system pkgs here.

Also, will the base OS be Ubuntu 20.04 for now or might it be feasible to develop on 22.04 prerelease directly in order to skip one update cycle?

I picked Apache and Exim from distro packages because that's consistent with how we're running our other services (e.g. Gerrit), and don't personally see the benefit of running them from containers when they don't really change significantly from one distro version to the next anyway. I'll update to mention it.

I expect we'll build on whatever our default distribution is when work begins, which is likely to be Ubuntu 20.04 LTS if we're starting on it in the next few weeks (trying to chase 20.04 LTS 6 months before it releases could be painful). I'll mention 20.04 LTS or current default in the servers section below.

I don't get the impression Nginx is the "default in that ecosystem" it's just what happens to be documented on one of the examples. Sticking with Apache for consistency with our other systems is likely to be a greater benefit to us. I'll note that as the reason I suggested Apache.

So this sounds like you would opt for apache because that's what we have in a lot of other places already? I won't object to that, just questioning whether instead going with what seems to be the default in that ecosystem (nginx) might mean less adaption work to do in the long run.
Thanks, fixing.
node

Unknown until we test, so yes we should check such things. Some headers will almost certainly change or be added, though hopefully the ones people tend to filter on like List-Id will stay the same. I'll note to check these, thanks.
Will handling of bounces and messages from non-subscribers change? Might be worth mentioning to check that. Also changes to list-related mail headers that people might be using for filtering.

We previously didn't add HTTPS because of the way the MM2 doesn't bother to safeguard its user authentication over other channels, so we didn't want to give our users the impression that the credentials they were supplying to the service were secure in any way. The more modern authentication in MM3 is really the fix here, so switching from HTTP to HTTPS is merely a side effect (HTTPS isn't a *feature* in and of itself, but rather a necessary implementation detail).

Yeah, I mean there are a number of incentives for upgrading listed here, a majority of which I didn't bother to enumerate either: https://docs.list.org/en/latest/migration.html#why-upgrade

Similarly we could add HTTPS to the existing MM2 deployment fairly trivially if we wanted, but we *need* it for MM3.

afaict the current servers don't do https for the web servers, but that would be a very welcomed and important addition.

You even could add lack of https to the problem description, as it is regularly popping up when browsing in https-only mode.

I was mainly thinking about browsing the archives and providing privacy against eavesdropping while doing so, which I do consider a feature. But if you argue that this feature isn't directly tied to the upgrade and thus shouldn't have focus here, I'm fine with that.

doc/source/backup/openstack/restore-open.message:
is there not a substitution for the openstack application name ?
i.e. downstream partner may have renamed
Yes, |prefix|. This should be applied globally.

I think these will break when built downstream, because prefix is 2 chars instead of 3 in that context. We have a substitution |s| to fix this. If you add it after the string containing |prefix| and before the next column, it will add 0 spaces to the stx build, but 1 space DS.

Same applies elsewhere in ascii tables of course.

@Ron, the substitution isn't working here, any guesses what I'm doing wrong? 
Line 56 works fine.

@Mary - the problem is that the substitution is abutting the equal sign. There are some limits in the characters they can be next to, mostly alphanumeric, but also '='. It works if a space is added, but then the assignment may not work.

My idea is that if e.g. I have an egress NP that only allows traffic to a namespace that doesn't yet have CIDR, then the SG rule will not get created for that namespace and after the namespace finally gets the CIDR, nothing will trigger reevaluation of the NP.

4. create pod (this will trigger creation of kuryrnetwork CRD and update of the sg rules)

The thing here is, it is loaded as a list of admin meta items and we've to traverse from it to find the admin meta we are looking for i.e. key='temporary' value='True'

-1: This field is being lazy loaded because on L1436 we use the generic model_query method that doesn't do the joined load.  The lazy loading relies on the session used to load the data being alive, and if it isn't then we'll get an error.

cinder/volume/manager.py.message:
I think this is a misuse of the disabled_reason field ... the field is there to explain why the cinder service itself is disabled, whereas you want to explain why replication is disabled on the backend, which is a bit different.

Feel free to bring this up at the virtual midcycle this week.

Here the use case is user is trying to initialize the replication backend which consists of primary site and secondary site. 

During initialization because of some reason any of the site may be down and we are setting service replication_status as disabled. So to give info to user we are using disabled_reason to explain why replication is disabled.

My preference would be that we not rely on RDO packages during the build process as much as possible as the rdo package repos haven't always been the most relaible.

Instead I think we can either wait for haveged to be part of the operating system or find an alternative or centos-9 can happen without entropy generation and maybe that will convince people to get entropy generation into the distro :)

ok, i'll just remove it.

Since centos8, rng-tools package included in RHEL/Centos and installed by default in dib images includes support for jitter entropy source by default when a better generator is not found, so I guess using rngd should be good enough?

BTW, as RDO maintainer, i'd like to know what have been the issues with rdo packages in the past. Said that, i agree in the general goal of minimizing repositories during build.
